So ....... LFL better, guidance unchanged, management tone is more optimistic than pessimistic.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Q1 retail sales of £498m, beating UBSe (£493m) by 1%. LFL is at +4% (UBSe and
cons +2%), with space -1.5% (UBSe -1.2%), leaving organic growth +2% (UBSe +1%).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: In Q1 APAC grew high-single digit with Mainland China up mid-teens, thanks to
repatriation of Chinese spend. Products from Riccardo Tisci's new collection have
grown at double-digit reaching 50% of assortment by the end of June.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: No change to FY20 guidance except FX headwind (now expected to be £15m versus
£-7m previously, UBSe £15m). Current EBIT consensus is unlikely to change.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: We would expect the LFL beat to be taken well by the market, although following
last month's share price move (+14% vs. sector +7%) buy-side expectations may have
been higher. The conference call at 9am UK-time will be key with management's
comments on H2-weighted profitability and impact of reduced markdowns in H2.

BE11:13am

Morgan Stanley off the conference call.

BE11:13am

one on the conference call was confident and reassuring. The CFO seems to be in good control of the restructuring plan and with a clear idea of the pace and quantum of the progress. Still, guidance remains a touch prudent reflecting all the different moving parts underlying the plan. All in all, we think the call was an incremental positive today and we would expect investors to gain confidence on the equity story.Key takeaways: 1) Differently from our original expectations, LFL strength was not driven by incremental discounting, but mainly from the success of the new collections, particularly in the Apparel range and among Chinese nationals (up high single digit in the quarter). This was a key surprise to us, given that our channel checks were not pointing to an improvement in momentum in the recent months.2) In terms of progression through the year, we should expect LFL to accelerate slightly in Q2, to slow down in Q3 (below 4%) and then to re-accelerate in Q4, reflecting the markdown comp base from FY19. The comp base should be 'clean' from FY21 (when we expect LFL to accelerate to 5.5-6.0%).3) Guidance on margins remain cautious: as the company invests into the new product range, we should expect Gross Margin to be penalised (-100bps in FY20) and then to slowly recover afterwards. All in all, we continue to expect a flattish EBIT margin in FY20 vs. FY19 with profits in H1 down low single digit yoy.4) Appetite from Chinese customers was very strong, which represents a good read-across also for the other luxury names (this cluster seems to have seen no slowdown industry-wise in Q2). Interestingly, while HK was penalised by the protests, sales were down only 'slightly' in the quarter, suggesting no major disruption.We still expect consensus to move up by c. mid single digit on the back of the release and conference call, mainly driven by FX upgrades. Although we would not be surprised to see investors becoming more constructive on the medium-term LFL profile given the positive surprise today and the confident tone from management.

Punter Re today's knife catch, AG Barr down 25%, the p/e at 650p on reduced 2019 forecast is 26 which seems to me a full valuation so am not tempted to buy for a bounce, but was wrong not to do so with Lookers last week which did seem cheap, so am probably wrong again. One of the reasons for the high rating I think is its a Lindsell Train favourite stock but will be interested to hear the latest broker take on it.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

This morning AG Barr have issued a profit warning with full year profit expected to be down by up to 20% versus consensus estimates of up 5%. This means a full year £10m profit reduction on adj profit last year of £46m. Management expect the first half to be down -10% to the region of £123m vs our below consensus estimate of £137m.

The company has taken price this year across its core brands, in particular Irn Bru, and this combined with the weak weather/underlying market has resulted in materially weaker trading. Management is citing a combination of weak trading in Rockstar and Rubicon along with poor summer weather. Water is expected to be worst hit due to the poor weather and its sensitivity to weather conditions.

BE11:23am

The next 6-10 weeks will be critical for the stock with new formulations and product launches along with the rest of Summer trading. Further risk to profits cannot be ruled out with tough comps and any further weather impacts.

We expect significant weakness this morning as the stock has been trading on above historical multiples at 25.1x 1 year forward earnings a 26% premium to beverages.

BE11:25am

As per RBC.

BE11:25am

Given Britvic’s significant exposure to the UK soft drinks market (60% of sales) we think this is a negative readacross. We expect Britvic to be similarly impacted by poor
weather, tough comparatives (predominantly in GB Stills) and weak trading in the impulse category (a direct impact of poor weather in our opinion) although not
necessarily the brand specific issues that AG Barr refer to. We note that comparatives are easier in GB Carbonates given the CO2 shortage last year.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

BE11:26am

Limited growth prospects thanks to its over-reliance on the soft drinks category and developed markets, together with the risks associated with Brexit and the soft
drinks levy in the UK (the company’s biggest market) mean that Britvic’s discount to the sector is justified in our opinion.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

CRH announced this morning (16 July 2019) it had reached an agreement to sell its European Distribution business to Blackstone for an EV of €1.64bn (€1.7bn incl. contingent consideration). This implies an EV/EBITDA multiple of nearly 11x (2018 pro forma/2019E), well above CRH’s own trading multiple of 8x but more in line with last year’s disposals of its Benelux DIY (9-10x) and Americas Distribution (13-14x) businesses. CRH announced a strategic review of its European Distribution division last year.
While we derive our CRH price target on a returns-based framework for the entire group, in our previous SOTP analysis we assumed an EV/EBITDA range between 7x-9x for the divisions, including Distribution. For illustrative purposes, applying the delta vs. the reported transaction multiple for CRH’s Europe Distribution business would imply, all else equal, a valuation uplift to our SOTP of between €0.4-€0.8 per CRH share (1-3% on today’s close). Equally, the balance sheet would be further strengthened (2018 pro forma ND/EBITDA on the above transaction value would be 1.7x, vs. 2.1x reported), supporting the current attractive total shareholder returns (6% buyback + divi, 2019E). Overall, we see the announcement as an incremental positive for the shares. We are Buy-rated, with a 12m price target of €34.

Excel Developer @BE: #CRH Why does EV/EBITDA vary so much from P/E of 17.52? Aren't they similar (on both numerator and denominator)?
BE11:38am

...... nope. Maybe Jefferies can?

FATDAZ @AM 3.38 am in LA
BE11:39am

The total value of the cash and lease adjusted debt of the balance sheet from the
deal is €1.94bn which is almost exactly aligned with the value that was included in
our sum of parts. Our sum of parts suggests a group valuation of €34.4/share based
on trading multiples and €40-48/share when including a replacement valuation of
the US aggregates and cement operations. Post the disposal of this business, we
forecast group sales by FY20 to be 60% Americas (20% Products, 40% Materials) and
EBITDA a more pronounced 65% Americas (17% Products, 48% Materials).
We have adjusted our P&L forecasts for this disposal: for ease, we have
deconsolidated it from start July 19. CRH reports it will look to use the proceeds
for "general corporate purposes, value creating acquisitions and capital returns to
shareholders through the ongoing share buyback programme". This suggests that
deployment of the proceeds may be used across a range of uses rather than one big
deal which may be seen as a less risky option. Investors may look for the next update
on share buybacks at the 1H19 results (22 Aug) given the current €350m buyback
ends in August. In our model, without including the redeployment of these proceeds
(we have debt paydown but assume a relatively low interest benefit), this disposal
is dilutive to EPS, albeit significantly accretive to EBITDA margins. Reflecting this
higher margin and a slightly lower cost of debt in the price target DCF drives an
increase in the CRH price target to €33.4

We upgrade to HOLD with 1,000p PT (1,050p). We were hoping for more, but the shape of upcoming Q2 results, excess profit reliance on Specials/Collectibles and on-going liquidity risk keep us on the sideline. Operating drivers will look significantly more attractive than auto peers in 2020, with DBX launch, no major CO2 constraint and a bumper year for Specials but these are fairly reflected in multiples considering execution risk and profit lumpiness.
